Global Center for Science and Engineering, Waseda University Tokyo Japan Furfural (FAL) is a versatile platform molecule for its use in synthesizing fuels and valuable chemicals. It is mainly derived from lignocellulosic biomass through acid-catalyzed dehydration of hemicellulose. Around 65% of the global production of furfural is used for the synthesis of furfuryl alcohol (FOL) due to its use in many industries. However, the use of high-pressure hydrogen gas systems for direct hydrogenation has led to the research of alternative methods. Here, we report our computational mechanistic investigation of a cobalt-based catalyst synthesized using a ligand derived from 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde and 4-nitroaniline in the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol using isopropanol as the hydrogen donor. This study presents the reaction energies of two hypothesized mechanisms in the gas phases and supplemental data on the noncovalent interactions therein. These findings suggest that the catalyst can facilitate the hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol through a reaction analogous to the Meerwein–Ponndorf–Verley reaction mechanism. Graphical abstract Keywords Furfuryl alcohol Furfural Hydrogenation Density-functional theory Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The pursuit of applicable alternatives to petroleum feedstock has made chemicals derived from lignocellulosic agricultural biomass very desirable for its benign effects on the environment and industrial application [1,2]. Furfural (FAL) is a platform molecule that has been researched due to its versatility in being a precursor of many high-value molecules and its renewability [3]. It is mainly derived from lignocellulosic biomass through acid-catalyzed dehydration of hemicellulose [4]. Lignocellulose is mainly obtained as the byproduct of sugar cane production, but is also obtained through rice straw, corncob, palm fruit bunches, and bamboo fiber production, which is why the furfural industry has been growing rapidly in countries that produce a large amount of agricultural biomass [5,6]. The cyanation, oxidation, or hydrogenation of furfural are the main processes in which it is converted, the latter of which could yield furfuryl alcohol. In fact, around 65% of the global production of furfural is converted to furfuryl alcohol (FOL). This is mainly due to the numerous applications and processes that utilize furfuryl alcohol for its environmental stability [7]. Its use ranges from being used to synthesize vitamin C and lysine in the pharmaceutical industry to being polymerized to be used in thermoset resins, adhesives, and foundry resins [8,9]. The production of furfuryl alcohol from furfural is predominantly produced via two methods: direct hydrogenation using hydrogen gas [10], or catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) [11,12], which utilizes alcohols or organic acids as the hydrogen donor. However, due to the precautions needed in handling high-pressure fossil-derived hydrogen gas, research on CTH has become a highly attractive approach for the biomass-based hydrogenation of furfural. Both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts have been found to facilitate the hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol [13]. Metal complexes are common homogeneous catalyst candidates for the hydrogenation process, as the variation of ligands can modify the electronic properties of the metal center and steric hindrance effects [14,15]. The bidentate phenoxyimine ligand has been widely used in metal complex catalysts, such as its use in the oligomerization of ethylene to linear α -olefins where it forms a nickel(II) bis(phenoxyimine) complex [16]. Matsubara et al. have used cobalt(II) bis(phenoxyimine) complexes to form active metal hydride intermediates as seen in the hydroxylation of ketone [17]. The hydroxylated ketone could then be further deprotected to form an alcohol. However, the deprotecting step is inefficient if we aim to solely produce the alcohol product. Through computational calculations based on a modified catalyst utilized by Matsubara et al. we aim to explore its role in the possible hydrogenation of FAL to FOL. In the present work, we evaluate two hypothesized reaction mechanisms of a novel cobalt(II) bis(phenoxyimine) catalyst synthesized using a ligand derived from 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde and 4-nitroaniline in the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol using isopropanol as the hydrogen donor using computational methods modeled, which yielded the furfuryl alcohol product. Calculations for both a high-spin and low-spin pathway were analyzed, and non-covalent interactions as well as charge density difference (CDD) analysis were employed to elucidate further the intramolecular and intermolecular interactions between the catalysts and the coordinated moieties. 2 Computational details Geometry optimization and Hessian calculations were performed using the unrestricted DFT method utilizing Gaussian 16 Rev.C.01 [18]. Before the geometry optimization using Gaussian, the geometries of all intermediates were preliminarily optimized and at the GFN2-xTB [19] level. The ω B97X-D [20] functional was utilized for the geometry optimization and Hessian calculations. The 6-31G(d,p) basis set [21] was used for the oxygen, carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen atoms. The Stuttgart RSC 1997 basis set with the effective core potential (ECP) [22] was used for the cobalt atom. All calculations were performed in the gas phase, as isopropanol is gaseous at the experimental temperature of 438.15 K. The same functional and basis sets were used at the DFT level for Non-Covalent Interaction (NCI) analysis using NCIPLOT to obtain the final output files for visualization [23]. Additionally, the Conformer–Rotamer Ensemble Sampling Tool (CREST) was utilized to obtain the most probable geometry candidate. The use of CREST [24] and optimization at the GFN2-xTB method is believed to aid the initial guess for the saddle point optimization at the DFT level. The optimized transition states have been verified to have only one imaginary frequency, and the spin contamination of each intermediate and transition state is within the acceptable boundaries of error, as shown in detail within the supporting information. The multiplicity of all high-spin stationary points is 4 (S = 3/2) with a charge of 0 except for the transition state of TS 1C-1D, which has a charge of 1 and a multiplicity of 5 (S = 2). The multiplicity of all low-spin stationary points is 2 (S = 1/2) and a charge of 0 except for the transition state of TS 1C-1D, which has a charge of 1 and a multiplicity of 1 (S = 0). The calculations were performed at 438.15 K and 1 atm in the gas phase to best reflect the experimental conditions that were utilized, as shown in Table 1. Normally, the reaction takes place in the autoclave, so that it maximizes the contacts between catalyst and substrates at a high temperature regime, as also reported for other cobalt complexes [25]. The zero-point vibrational energies, thermal corrections to internal energies, enthalpies, and Gibbs free energies were calculated, while the Gibbs energies were used to construct the energy diagram. The ligands (L) of the CoL2 catalyst is (E)-2-(((4nitrophenyl)imino)methyl)phenol. The L is then varied for mechanism 2, as it is concluded as the most plausible mechanism. Furthermore, the nucleophilic and electrophilic Fukui functions of each intermediate were calculated to obtain a dual descriptor for nucleophilicity and electrophilicity by using MultiWFN [26]. The condensed dual descriptor Δ f is described in (1). (1) Δ f ( r ) = f + ( r ) − f − ( r ) = ρ n + 1 ( r ) − 2 ρ n ( r ) + ρ n − 1 ( r ) The negative and positive Fukui functions f − ( r ) and f + ( r ) were obtained through electron density calculations of each intermediate geometry in the anionic and cationic states. The electron densities of the anionic, cationic, and neutral states are denoted as ρ n − 1 ( r ) , ρ n + 1 ( r ) , and ρ n ( r ) . The Fukui functions are described in the equations below. (2) f − ( r ) = ρ n ( r ) − ρ n − 1 ( r ) (3) f + ( r ) = ρ n + 1 ( r ) − ρ n ( r ) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Calculation of initial catalyst conformers The structure of the cobalt(II) complexes can vary depending on the magnetic moment of the structure. A magnetic moment of around 4.2–4.7 BM would suggest a tetrahedral structure with a quartet spin (S = 3/2) at a high-spin state, whereas a magnetic moment of around 2.1–2.9 BM would form a square planar complex with a singlet spin (S = 1/2) at a low spin-state [27,28]. Geometry optimizations of three possible conformations were performed to obtain the most stable conformation of the complex at 438.15 K. As shown in Table 2, the tetrahedral conformer of the cobalt complex with the quartet spin is found to be the most stable conformation at this temperature in comparison to the square planar conformations with singlet spin by 21.82 kcal/mol less than the cis square planar conformation and 15.95 kcal/mol less than the trans square planar conformation. Research suggests that the high-spin state of the tetrahedral cobalt complex is most likely at this temperature; thus, a high-spin state complex will be used primarily as the starting geometry for the catalyst in all of the geometric optimization calculations. All intermediates and transition state optimization converged successfully with minimum spin contamination. FT-IR absorption peaks of the catalyst obtained from both DFT frequency calculations and experimental measurements were compared to corresponding literature values in Table 3. The difference between the experimental measurement and DFT calculation is considered to be within the common bounds of error for DFT frequency calculations [29]. The agreeable values of the two methods shows that the geometry of the catalyst used for the DFT calculations reflect the experimentally synthesized catalyst. 3.2 Proposed mechanisms of FAL to FOL hydrogenation In the present work, two mechanism schemes are proposed. Scheme 1, as shown in Fig. 1, begins with the coordination of isopropanol to the cobalt center of the catalyst, followed by the abstraction of the hydrogen from the hydroxyl group of isopropanol to the oxygen of the ligand. This is then followed by the abstraction of the β -hydrogen of the furfural to the cobalt, forming a cobalt hydride species and acetone. The acetone is subsequently dissociated from the cobalt center, allowing a furfural species to coordinate in its place. Then, hydrogen abstraction occurs in the ligand, followed by the transfer of the hydride from the cobalt center to the coordinated furfural, which then forms furfuryl alcohol. Scheme 2, as shown in Fig. 2, involves a simultaneous coordination of furfural and isopropanol to the cobalt center. The isopropanol and furfural then proceed to form a pericyclic transition state, followed by a simultaneous hydrogen transfer that occurs between the hydrogen of the hydroxyl group and the hydrogen of the β -carbon of the isopropanol to the furfural, forming furfuryl alcohol. Aside from the hypothesized mechanisms above, the possible reduction of the nitroarene group raise concerns regarding the chemical stability of the spent catalyst. The reduction of the nitro group of the catalyst to an amine requires specific conditions that the model reaction, shown in Table 1, does not facilitate. The chemoselective reduction of a nitroarene most often requires the presence of a strong acid, water, or hydrogen gas and a suitable metal catalyst to facilitate the nitro-group hydrogenation [31–33]. However, the most readily available hydrogen donor in our model reaction is isopropanol. For the nitro group to be hydrogenated by the hydrogen of the isopropanol, a highly selective catalytic transfer of hydrogen must occur. A paper by V.P. Sivcev et al. describes a reaction that theoretically could occur in our model reaction, in which a metal catalyst facilitates the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of a nitroarene using isopropanol as a hydrogen donor [34]. That said, the specific reaction used Al2O3 as a catalyst and reported that such hydrogenation only substantially occurred at temperatures above 543.15 K at a pressure of around 200 atm in a flow reactor and yielded various byproducts. In contrast, the temperature used in the model reaction is considerably lower at 438.15 K and at a much lower pressure of 1 atm. Considering these factors, as well as the absence of byproducts of nitroarene reduction like H2O, as shown in Table 1, we believe that the catalyst presented in the study would not undergo the reduction of its nitroarene group. The experimental characterization of the spent catalyst could further expand this point of discussion, however, we would like to affirm that this study aims to undertake the topic at hand from a computational lens. 3.3 Mechanism elucidation of FAL to FOL hydrogenation Each scheme begins with the tetrahedral catalyst precursor (1A). Isopropanol then coordinates to the cobalt center to form 1B. Upon coordination of the isopropanol, the phenoxyimine ligands shift such that the phenyl moieties of the two ligands overlap with each other and form a square pyramidal structure. The CDD of the cobalt center in 1B is negative, namely −0.0936, which makes it a preferable site for electrophilic attacks. The phenolic oxygen that is coordinated to the cobalt center also has a negative CDD of −0.0346. Both of these sites could abstract the hydroxyl hydrogen of the isopropanol due to having a much more negative CDD than the hydroxyl oxygen of −0.0084. However, the phenolic oxygen is closer to the hydroxyl hydrogen than the cobalt center, which makes it a more likely candidate for protonation. This abstraction of the hydroxyl hydrogen to the phenolic oxygen (TS 1B-1C) is an endergonic reaction with a Δ G ‡ of 14.37 kcal/mol. This reaction forms 1C in which the coordinate bond length of the deprotonated oxygen of the isopropanol shortens from 2.315 Å to 1.894 Å as the bond character becomes more ionic. In contrast, the coordinate bond length between the cobalt center and the phenolic oxygen of the ligand lengthens from 1.964 Å to 3.398 Å due to the abstracted hydrogen making the coordinate bond between the cobalt and the phenolic oxygen more covalent, this separation forms a terahedral structure in which the phenolic oxygen is no longer strongly coordinated to the cobalt center as seen in Fig. 4. The CDD of the phenolic oxygen changes to 0.0043 after its protonation, becoming more electrophilic. The cobalt center then becomes the most preferred site for an electrophilic attack with a CDD of −0.0184, namely by the hydrogen attached to the α -carbon of the isopropanol. The protonation of the cobalt center TS 1C-1D is a highly endergonic reaction with a positively charged transition state due to the carbocation formation resulting from the deprotonation of the α -carbon of the isopropanol. 1C-1D could be described as a β -H elimination since the deprotonated carbon is in the β position after coordination to the cobalt center in 1B. All intermediates and transition states from the starting catalyst (1A) up to 1C are considerably more stable as a high-spin complex as shown in the difference between the free energies of the two spin states at each stationary point in Fig. 3. This eliminates the possibility of a spin crossover occurring up to 1C. However, the free energy of the low-spin complex at TS 1C-1D (S = 0) is found to be less than that of its high-spin counterpart (S = 2). The oxidation of the cobalt species from to in TS 1C-1D at a low-spin completely fills the with paired electrons, leaving the orbital empty and creating a closed-shell system. This suggests a theoretical minimum energy crossing point in between 1C and TS 1C-1D in which an energetically favorable spin crossover from high-spin to low-spin may occur. In this case, the reaction proceeds from the high-spin 1C (S = 3/2) to the positively charged low-spin TS 1C-1D (S = 0) with a Δ G ‡ of 195.81 kcal/mol, slightly energetically favorable than the Δ G ‡ between 1C and the positively charged high-spin TS 1C-1D of 197.91 kcal/mol. The large Δ G ‡ of this process makes this reaction the most likely rate-determining step (RDS) of Scheme 1. After the protonation of the cobalt center, the acetone is then repelled further away as the protonated phenolic ligand shifts closer to the cobalt center once more, as seen in Fig. 4. The resulting intermediate (1D) forms a square pyramidal structure. Since the high-spin 1D complex (S = 3/2) has a lower free energy than that of its low-spin counterpart (S = 1/2), a spin crossover back to high-spin is more favorable for the reaction to proceed from the low-spin TS 1C-1D at a theoretical minimum energy crossing point between TS 1C-1D and 1D. From 1D, the high-spin complexes of all following intermediates and transition states are considerably less stable than that of their high-spin counterparts, suggesting that the reaction proceeds at a high-spin onwards until its completion. As the acetone fully leaves the reaction center, 1E is formed. The elimination of the acetone renders the cobalt hydride center nucleophilic with a CDD of −0.0193 for the cobalt itself and a CDD of −0.0135 for the hydride. The nucleophilic hydride center of the complex is then coordinated to FAL, forming 1F. This coordination is likely due to the interaction between the nucleophilic cobalt hydride center and the highly electrophilic carbonyl group of FAL. Upon the coordination of FAL, the complex forms an octahedral structure, and the cobalt hydride center becomes electrophilic with a CDD of 0.0686. In contrast, the hydride becomes nucleophilic with a CDD of −0.0833. The CDD of the cobalt and the hydride suggest that the intramolecular charge densities are not conducive to facilitating the abstraction of the hydride away from the cobalt center. However, the Δ G of 1E-1F of 5.64 kcal/mol suggests that the coordination of FAL introduces some instability. Fig. 5 shows that the steric hindrance as well as the distortion of the octahedral primary angles that form as the complex reorients into an octahedral structure, is likely to be the main contributor to this instability. The hydride migration from the cobalt center to the α -carbon of FAL moeity in 1F-1G then resolves the steric hindrance in 1F as shown through the exergonic Δ G of 1F-1G of −30.20 kcal/mol. This forms the square pyramidal complex seen in 1G. The hydride transfer reaction shifts the CDD of the carbonyl oxygen of the FAL moiety from a slightly nucleophilic CDD of −0.0074 in 1F to −0.0139, which is more nucleophilic than the −0.0105 of the cobalt center and the 0.0119 of the protonated phenolic oxygen. This makes it the most likely candidate for an electrophilic attack, namely, by the slightly electrophilic hydrogen currently bonded to the phenolic oxygen with a CDD of 0.0054. This final reaction seen in TS 1G-1H is an exergonic reaction that involves the electrophilic attack of the carbonyl oxygen by the hydrogen bonded to the phenolic oxygen to form the FOL moiety with a Δ G ‡ of 1.24 kcal/mol. This completes the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of FAL to FOL, as both hydrogens abstracted from isopropanol are transferred to the FAL moiety. The elimination of the coordinated FOL moiety then completes the mechanism proposed in Scheme 1. In contrast to scheme 1, where isopropanol transfers its hydroxyl hydrogen and α -H to the cobalt catalyst first prior to the FAL coordination and is hydrogenated to FOL, both FAL and isopropanol coordinate to the cobalt center before any hydrogen abstraction occurs in scheme 2. It seems that the initial coordination of isopropanol to the cobalt center (1B), shown in Fig. 3, is more energetically feasible than the FAL (2B). Both routes, however, involve the formation of a square pyramidal complex upon coordination. Then, the cobalt complex with the coordinated FAL (2B) or isopropanol (1B) coordinates with the remaining reactant to form an octahedral complex (2C) as seen in Fig. 7. From this octahedral formation, the FAL and isopropanol moieties interact to create a pericyclic transition state (TS 2C-2D) that is analogous to the transition state seen in a Meerwein–Ponndorff–Verley reaction, which has been observed in the hydrogenation of FAL to FOL on heterogeneous metal catalysts [35,36]. We can see the ring formation during the transition state in Fig. 7 from the ring torsion that forms within the pericyclic formation as shown by the red spherical isosurface within it. During this exergonic transition state, the hydrogen of the hydroxyl group of the isopropanol and its α -H are simultaneously transferred to the carbonyl oxygen and the α -carbon of the FAL moiety, respectively, to form FOL and acetone (2D). Since TS 2C-2D is the singular transition state in this proposed scheme, it is the hypothesized rate-determining step of scheme 2. In comparison to the hypothesized rate-determining step of scheme 1 (TS 1C-1D), the Δ G ‡ of TS 2C-2D has a much lower value of 38.47 kcal/mol. During the transition state, the hydroxylic oxygen of the furfuryl alcohol leaves the cobalt center as its interatomic distance increases from 2.300 Å in 2C to 3.814 Å in TS 2C-2D to form the observed pericyclic transition state. Then, the coordinated acetone and FOL moieties leave the cobalt center in succession. It is suggested that the isopropanol moiety is more likely to leave the cobalt center right after its oxidation to acetone, leaving a coordinated FOL moiety (1H), instead of the FOL (2E). After the remaining coordinated moiety is eliminated, the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of FAL to FOL according to the mechanism proposed in Scheme 2 is completed. All low-spin stationary points in Scheme 2 are considerably less stable than that of their high-spin counterparts, as shown in Fig. 6. The intermolecular forces of the coordinating substrates also do not provide enough external stimuli to initiate spin crossover of the complex. This shows that there are no minimum energy crossing points between the two spin-states for a feasible spin crossover to occur. Due to this, the reaction based on Scheme 2 should proceed at a high-spin from start to completion at 438.15 K, which agrees with prior research [27,28]. 3.4 Effects of ligand variation on activation energy in scheme 3 The bidentate ligand used in the Gibbs free energy calculations was chosen for its electron-withdrawing nitrous group at the para position, as research has suggested that a strong electron-withdrawing group contributes to the selectivity of the catalyst in this particular reaction. For this reason, Gibbs free energy calculations in the gas phase of scheme 2 utilizing different cobalt catalysts were done to see the effect of ligand variation on the Δ G ‡ TS 2C-2D. A bidentate ligand with a trifluoromethyl group at the para position and one with a trifluoromethyl group at the meta position were chosen. The trifluoromethyl group was selected for its powerful electron-withdrawing effects that hypothetically exceed those of the nitrous group. Scheme 2 was the only scheme calculated with varying ligands since it is the most likely reaction mechanism based on the analysis of the Gibbs free energy diagrams. The catalysts with a trifluoromethyl group at the meta position were seen to have a Δ G ‡ TS 2C-2D of 36.45 kcal/mol, which is 2.02 kcal/mol lower than that of the original catalyst. The catalyst with a trifluoromethyl group at the para position performed the best with a Δ G ‡ TS 2C-2D of 36.07 kcal/mol, which is 2.4 kcal/mol less than that of the original catalyst (see Figs. 8 and 9). CDD analysis of each ligand variation was done for 1A and TS 2C-2D to see the effects of the ligands on the nucleophilicity and electrophilicity of the cobalt center in order to gain insight on the differences in Δ G ‡ TS 2C-2D of the three ligands. The findings are tabulated in Table 4. The complex with the para-NO2 ligand has the most nucleophilic cobalt center in both 1A but the least nucleophilic cobalt in TS 2C-2D, with a CDD of −0.006 in 1A and −0.0154 in TS 2C-2D, has the highest Δ G ‡ TS 2C-2D of 38.47 kcal/mol. While the complex with the para-CF3 ligand has the second most electrophilic cobalt center in 1A, yet the most nucleophilic cobalt center in TS 2C-2D, with a CDD of 0.1097 and −0.1491 in 1A and TS 2C-2D respectively, has the lowest Δ G ‡ TS 2C-2D of 36.07 kcal/mol. The complex with the meta-CF3 ligand has the most electrophilic cobalt center in 1A, with a CDD of 0.1147, and the second most nucleophilic cobalt in TS 2C-2D, with a CDD of −0.0308, has a slightly higher Δ G ‡ TS 2C-2D of 36.45 kcal/mol in comparison to the para-CF3 variation. This implies that the CDD of the cobalt center in 1A correlates inversely ( R 2 = 0 . 9664 ) to a lower Δ G ‡ TS 2C-2D, while the CDD of the cobalt center in TS 2C-2D correlates proportionally ( R 2 = 0 . 4915 ) to a lower Δ G ‡ TS 2C-2D. Furthermore, much like the original catalyst, the low-spin complexes of all stationary points of both variants have considerably higher Gibbs free energies than their high-spin counterparts for Scheme 2. The conclusion that there would be no energetically feasible minimum energy crossing point for a spin crossover still holds for both of the ligand variations, and thus, the reaction will proceed via a high-spin pathway. 4 Conclusions A computational study on two hypothesized mechanisms for FAL to FOL hydrogenation utilizing a novel cobalt-based catalyst was conducted. Free energy calculations were conducted to obtain a diagram of the hypothesized intermediates and transitions in the two proposed mechanisms for both low-spin and high-spin complexes. Non-covalent interaction analysis and CDD analysis were used to supplement the elucidation of the reaction mechanisms. In terms of energetics, scheme 2 is much favored over scheme 1. The rate-determining step in scheme 2 (TS 2C-2D) has a much lower Δ G ‡ of 38.47 kcal/mol, which is minuscule in comparison to the Δ G ‡ of the high-spin 1C (S = 3/2) to the positively charged low-spin TS 1C-1D (S = 0) of scheme 1, namely 195.81 kcal/mol. Analysis of the geometric structure and non-covalent interaction of 1C also suggests that such a reaction is unlikely to occur. Therefore, scheme 2, which proceeds via a high-spin pathway, is considered the most probable reaction mechanism for the hydrogenation of furfural (FAL) to furfuryl alcohol (FOL) catalyzed by the cobalt phenoxyimine complex employed in this study. With this conclusion in mind, we calculated the free energies of not-yet-synthesized ligand variations of this catalyst for scheme 2 as a suggestion for further experiments regarding this topic. Analysis suggests that the strong electron-withdrawing properties of the trifluoromethyl group at the para position lower the Δ G ‡ of TS 2C-2D in comparison to the original catalyst. Since this transition step is the rate-determining step of scheme 2, the catalyst with the trifluoromethyl group at the para position may outperform the original catalyst and is a good candidate for experimental synthesis. Similarly, in other fields, such as in drug discovery and medicinal chemistry, deciphering reaction mechanisms becomes important, for example, in the inhibition of acetylcholinesterase and butyrylcholinesterase [37]. The enzyme kinetics therein can be studied via combined DFT and semi-empirical techniques. CRediT authorship contribution statement Abel D.F. coredata.dc:description: Furfural (FAL) is a versatile platform molecule for its use in synthesizing fuels and valuable chemicals. It is mainly derived from lignocellulosic biomass through acid-catalyzed dehydration of hemicellulose. Around 65% of the global production of furfural is used for the synthesis of furfuryl alcohol (FOL) due to its use in many industries. However, the use of high-pressure hydrogen gas systems for direct hydrogenation has led to the research of alternative methods. Here, we report our computational mechanistic investigation of a cobalt-based catalyst synthesized using a ligand derived from 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde and 4-nitroaniline in the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol using isopropanol as the hydrogen donor. This study presents the reaction energies of two hypothesized mechanisms in the gas phases and supplemental data on the noncovalent interactions therein. These findings suggest that the catalyst can facilitate the hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol through a reaction analogous to the Meerwein–Ponndorf–Verley reaction mechanism.
